body:
Hi! I´m trying to model a horizontal shading slate that is offset above the start of the window and/or extends beyond the side edges of the window. I seems that E+ only allows me to stay within the window boundaries. Im just about to give up on using the E+ [WindowMaterial:Shade](http://bigladdersoftware.com/epx/docs/8-3/input-output-reference/group-surface-construction-elements.html#windowmaterialshade) components for this task but then I got some confusing hope by the E+ manual when I saw the "OtherShadingType", and some other ways that I might be able to input what I wanted.

Does anyone have any insight into the limitations and workarounds of E+ on this?  Note: I´d prefer not to use a context geometry because I want the thermal properties like radiation balance and so on to be calculated.

replies.body:
Hi Ludvig,

as you said there are some limitations for thermal analysis using outdoor shading in E+;

actually, the "OtherShadingType" allows you to "describe" your custom and complex geometry as you prefer...you should type you own IDF file  and adding to ADDITIONAL STRING into the E+ calculator component, here some examples of the IDF file:

[http://bigladdersoftware.com/epx/docs/8-3/input-output-reference/gr...](http://bigladdersoftware.com/epx/docs/8-3/input-output-reference/group-surface-construction-elements.html#windowmaterialcomplexshade)

It could be helpful if you could share some image or file of your shading..anyway please have a look at this discussion:

[http://www.grasshopper3d.com/group/ladybug/forum/topics/hb-shading-...](http://www.grasshopper3d.com/group/ladybug/forum/topics/hb-shading-context-transmaterial-fails?commentId=2985220%3AComment%3A1471159&xg_source=msg_com_gr_forum)

I hope that this helps

Ernesto

Thanks for the reply. After reading this I reckon it wont be worth the trouble. 

"While this may seem like the best of all worlds, it is usually VERY time-consuming to pull off as you have to parameterize the geometry into a matirx of values for the amount of sun that is permitted for every sun angle."

I will try to quantify the difference in zone energy needs that only using context geometry imposes and live with the shortcomming.
